Hail and well met! *waves*
Did you say that you played the OC, SoU, and HotU with the same character? Both the OC and SoU are supposed to start at level 1, and HotU is for the character that finished SoU, not the OC.
If you want to continue after the OC, you might like the Aribeth Redemption series, but be advised, it is a love story between  the player character and Aribeth. You wll end up at about level 28, same as HotU.
If you want to continue after HotU (or after Aribeth's Redemption), you might like the Sands of Fate series. These will take you all the way to level 40.
Another campaign I highly recommend is the Aielund Saga, which will take you from level 1 to about level 36 or so.
You should be able to find these modules at http://neverwintervault.org/

For dual-wielding, the off-hand weapon needs to be small or tiny, or you will get a -2 penalty on your AB. To reduce the number of feats needed, we usually use the same weapon in both hands. I could make for you a dual Short Sword Elf Bard / Fighter / Red Dragon Disciple, if you like that idea.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Oh man, you are like a blank Canvas ready to be painted to a masterpiece!

If you show even remotely the same affection you did for Baldur's Gate, for Neverwinder Nights you are in for a treatment i promise you that. Neverwinder Nights is probably one of the most beloved rpg games ever created and it's fanbase is fanatically loyal to it, thus they have created over three thousand modules for the game, making it almost limitless in scope. You will probably hear a lot of things suggested from us on these forums and understandingly not all of them will make sense to you at the beginning but be patient and ask and you will be rewarded. If you don't know or have doubts about something then ask freely, we are more than happy to share our knowledge with you. At this point i don't even know if you do know, how to install a module or how to join a Persistent World so i will cut on the overload of information that i am ready to impart on you and talk about two things only, the second one being your build, but the first one...

1st) Most important thing you have to experience about Neverwinder Nights is to join a Persistent World. Seriously, join a Persistent World if you haven't done so already. The Original Trilogy and all the additional (and vastly superior) modules that we are going to suggest to you over time will be always there as long as your hard drive exists and you can play them solo or with friends (LAN) whenever you want but after a decade of furious action the online community is starting to decline already. So, jump over there while you can and join a good Persistent World and experience what is like to have actual people in your team, adventure together and defeat all kinds of foes the Persistent World has to offer. It is totally free, no montly fees or whatever, they have Dungeon Masters online who interact with you real time and shape your adventures, you can drink in taverns with your team and joke about, share treasure, do almost anything, man is f a n t a s t i c !

2nd) Alrighty, about your build i would almost echo Empyre's suggestions but... this is the Original Trilogy right? And i pressume with no additional Haks or whatever like Tonyk's A.I or anything else, so anything works. You don't even need a power build for that, a naked character with one of Rizolvir's weapons could solo Mephisto with ease. You can even take a Cloak that makes you effectively immune to hostile magic and a Breastplate that makes you immune to Sneak attacks as well. Even as early as the first module (O.C) you can have a belt that makes all enemies do next to no melee damage to you. I don't know if you are aware for these items so i won't spoil them to you except if you ask, but the point is that you can afford (especially with a power build) to have any weapons that you like to have and take the -4 AB penalty with little to no consequences whatsoever. So, if you want some suggestions for weapons i say go with hammers and bastard swords, cause they look badass and you can have the hammer of thunderbolts and bloodletter swinging at the same time! With some Red Dragon Disciple treatment and -later- Devastating Critical you will feel like Theseus and everything that dare comes before you will be dealt swiftly and mercilessly. And here is a hint for ya, if you like to keep Aribeth and generally have the NPC's be really nice to you, then put full ranks into Persuade skill, you will never regret this for the Original Trilogy as it is ideal for a Paladin - like hero ;)

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Straight for the answers,

a) Unfortunately Elves are implemented very badly in 3rd ed. of ADnD, until we meet the Sun Elves in Faerun, what's strange is that although Neverwinter Nights takes indeed place on Faerun it has not implemented the Sun Elves as a sub-race, or Drow for that matter, leaving us with a totally worthless base Elven race that has no affiliations whatsoever with magic- that is supported at least by the rules. They could at least have as favored class the Ranger and that would make sense since at least Rangers can make use of the dexterity bonus but instead we get Mages. Truth is that the stock Elves makes absolutely the worst Mages possible and here is the Irony, Dwarves makes (alongside Gnomes) the best! Chief reason that we take Elves in Neverwinter Nights is either role-playing or PvP. Don't ask for now, " why " for the later because this will take some time to explain and you won't be interested in (P)layer (V)s (P)layer maches for a while. Ah, okay we choose Elves for Arcane Archers too i suppose, we can't avoid that since it is a requirement heh.

b) The answer to which armour is the best for your type is better given from Minsc himself ~ Full Plate and Packing Steel !
And there is a reason for that too, as implemented in Neverwinter Nights, the Full Plate will always give you the best AC possible unless you build a dexterity-based character (do that afterwards - is fun). Going with medium armor should be based primarily on the special properties of the armour. For example, you remember the Djinni you can take with you in HoTU and has a special store that you can buy things from? He sells the " Lesser Golem Armour ",  now that armour is a prime example for which one may choose to have less AC from what a Full Plate gives to get some really powerful properties. But plain and simple if you want the best AC around then it is always the Full Plate! (no Shadow Dragon Armour/ White Dragon Scale here, heh).

c) As far as your build is concerned don't take into consideration spellcasting at all. The Bard's Song is a feat essentially thus it is not subject to arcane spell-failure like normal spells. Sing as much as you like!

d) Ah the skills, alright here is how it goes:
The first number is the actual ranks you put into them and then the second number in the brackets is the modified ranks you will have (the real number) as they are affected by your ability scores and synergies. In most cases the second number is what you should be looking at but there are few examples that the first number is all that we care for. A prime example of that would be (Tumble: 40 (43)) As long as we have forty ranks in "Tumble" we get the maximum possible AC bonus (+8) for our build, so the number in the brackets means nothing to us, but for all the rest of your skills the number in the brackets is what the real value of that skill is.

Good Hunting!

I am using the in-game character customizer override that allows you to modify the looks of your equipment to whatever you want, so you don't look like a crappy piece of sh*t all the time. It's a very simple task to do, you just download this very small file and then throw the contents in your "override folder" in your NwN1 installation directory.

Character Customizer ->  http://neverwintervault.org/project/nwn ... e-hak-ccoh

After you finish the O.C you will want to start another module, maybe it is HoTU or Aribeth's module, no matter what the process is the same for all. You download the module and unjip it to an empty folder. The files from Neverwinter Nights Vault might have several sub-files in them but each one has an extension that you must follow. For example a module like HoTU needs no *haks or anything else so you just launch NwN1 then select the HoTU campaign and then you select your hero that you finished the O.C plain and simple. But another module that you download from the Vault might have several files in it when you unzip it. Take note at the extensions of the files, and do the following.

a) If the module has files that end in *hak name, those you take and put into your corresponding *hak folder in your NwN1 installation directory
b) If the module has files that end in *mod name, those you take and put into your corresponding *module folder in your NwN1 installation directory
c) If the module has files that end in *bmu name, those you take and put into your corresponding *music folder in your NwN1 installation directory
d) If the module has files that end in *erf name, those you take and put into your corresponding *erf folder in your NwN1 installation directory

Basically it's a plain "copy and paste" of the various files that a zip file might have into your corresponding folders in your NwN1 installation directory. More often than not, the modules you are going to download will have a single *mod file in them, zipped for economy on size. You can then play those modules, simply by going to the "New Module" Tab of your start menu in NwN1 and then selecting the module you want to play. Then you can import any character that you like or start the module with a fresh level 1 character. Most if not all of the modules will specify in their description the level range that each module is best to start with, just as HoTU says in it's description it is best for levels 13 to 16.
